Never used Ayahuasca.  Am pro MMJ for a lot of reasons and prefer to see the use of natural alternative to medications (and I do believe in LSD treatments for PTSD, people with chronic conditions, migraines, etc).  With that said, I've known several people who have done Ayahuasca.  They were very wonderful and creative people.  One of them was a poet/artist.  After they took it, it's as though they became cold toward people/the world and abstractly self focused.  Their writings changed, becoming mundane and the art stopped all together.  It was as though they lost the light in their soul/eyes.  Even after years, they never regained that light (or only slightly regained it).  I've yet to see anyone bounce back from it fully.  My friends who did it, did it under the influence of different shamans (which I don't believe in) at different times and different places.  Before you do this drug, meet people before they do it and days after they do it.  You be the judge, I'm NEVER going to touch the stuff.

I feel like this could have benefited from a little more details about the vine. The ingredient in the vine that allows the DMT to get into the blood and pass into the brain is a MAO Inhibitor.  MAOIs prevent the body from breaking down many types of very dangerous toxins, and can even make some otherwise safe substances (e.g. caffeine) dangerous.  That is likely why people die from it: they don't avoid all the things you need to avoid when taking MAOIs.

If you want to have an experience that aya seems to promise, you don't have to pay thousands and thousands of dollars to go through a shamanic ritual in the Amazon. You can prepare a nice and comfortable setting to have a trip in and make your own brew or use mushrooms instead. ASAPScience has a great video about magic mushrooms as well.

And if you really want to dive into the deep end, smoked DMT is arguably as intense as it gets.

For people interested in Ayahuasca: it's traditionally used by native south American tribes, as the video tells. But please stop that "oh so you can get high, cool, I'll do it". It is completely disrespectful from the ancient cultures that have been using it for cultural and religious purposes, not just because "it's fun". You can get a pretty good idea of it from watching the colombian movie "The embrace of the Serpent", it was nominated for the Oscar this year, it's a really good film that attempts to show just what the Ayahuasca means for indigenous people in the Amazonian jungle.

This isn't to say "if you're not indigenous you can't do it", it's an invitation to please be respectful of the cultures who originally used this substances and get informed on what it actually means for them, before you jump on a plane just because you want to get high.

I've taken ayahuasca once, as part of a ceremony from a religious group called "União do Vegetal" - I experimented several ceremonies from several religions at the time.

As it was part of a ceremony, we were taken to a distant location, and during the 4+ hours the ceremony lasted after drinking the ayahuasca, there were no sounds but those of the nature around us and from the chants the four "elders" sang - a rhythmic, repetitive and monotonous song not unlike the "Oms" in Buddhism. They explained to the newcomers like myself how the evening would follow and the expected effects of the beverage - including the nausea and vomiting. One thing they said - and that really happened - and is not said in your great video, is that the ayahuasca makes us feel cold - they even provided blankets.

From my experience, I found that drinking it was not unlike having a high fever - including the sensation of cold. I was lightheaded and drowsy, and I only hallucinated when I "slept" - the same kind of weird minutes sleep we have when with a high fever. The effect lasted almost exactly the time they explained us it would, and I did felt nauseated afterwards. Apart from that, I didn't experienced any long-lasting effect and, since I look over the experience with a objective mind, didn't had any "revelation" or "mind-lightness" sensation as some other newcomers shared with me. My "hallucinations" also weren't as strong as some of the descriptions other people gave me - but again, I was probably less influenced by the ritualistic aspects of everything.

The beverage itself was just a small glass half-full with a thick dark green liquid which we were oriented to drink all at once - about 200ml or so. It's bitter and strong and not agreeable at all - which didn't prevented some of the older folks to repeat the dosage mid-ceremony.
If anyone wants to learn more then check out the documentary called "DMT The Spirit Molecule". I love DMT. Ingested a few times both inhaling pure DMT and drinking ayahuasca form.

DMT or Dimethyltryptamine, also where the word trip comes from, is produced by the Pineal Gland. Its production is the reasons we dream. The brain produces large quantities of it in REM Sleep and in the moments just before ones death, this explains why many people claim they see their entire lives flash before their eyes. The Pineal Gland in some animals actually takes on the form of a third eye. This is also the location of the third Eye Chakra. DMT occurs naturally in our environment. One can extract it from Mimosa hostilis root bark and other plants.
